channel.title: NPR Morning Edition
channel.description: Morning Edition takes listeners around the country and the world with multi-faceted stories and commentaries every weekday. Hosts Steve Inskeep, Leila Fadel, Michel Martin and A Mart√≠nez bring you the latest breaking news and features to prepare you for the day.

item.title: A look at Congress' decision to cede the 'power of the purse' to President Trump
item.description: NPR's Steve Inskeep talks with Politico's Jonathan Martin about Congress ceding the "power of the purse" over to President Trump.

item.title: What a possible release of grand jury testimony related to Jeffrey Epstein signifies
item.description: NPR talks with Sarah Isgur, senior editor with "The Dispatch," about the Trump administration's request to unseal grand jury testimony related to disgraced financier and sex offender Jeffrey Epstein.

item.title: Morning news brief
item.description: The latest on Israeli military attacks on Palestinians seeking aid in Gaza, lawyers for Harvard and Trump face off in court, Texas Republicans aim to redraw congressional districts in special session.

item.title: New Jersey school becoming major training ground for young people interested in jazz
item.description: A school in New Jersey - Jazz House - is becoming a major training ground for young people interested in jazz performance. This story is excerpted from a longer profile on NPR Music's Jazz Night in America.

item.title: A look at President Trump's foreign policy 6 months into his second administration
item.description: As a candidate, President Trump promised to change America's foreign policy. Six months into his second administration, NPR examines where things stand.

item.title: A hornet hunter's finds help make treatments for allergic reactions
item.description: Hornet hunters across the U.S. use the summer months to harvest the insects and sell them to a pharmaceutical company. It uses the venom to make a treatment for allergic reactions to their stings.

item.title: Former Louisville detective to be sentenced for role in Breonna Taylor's death
item.description: A former Louisville detective is expected to be sentenced Monday for his role in the botched raid that resulted in Breonna Taylor's death. He was convicted last year of violating her civil rights.

item.title: Some states aim to protect residents as private investors buy up mobile home parks
item.description: Manufactured homes are sometimes the last option for affordable housing. As private investors buy up parks, some states aim to protect residents from rapid rent increases.

item.title: The latest on Israeli military attacks on Palestinians seeking aid in Gaza
item.description: Gaza health officials say more than 100 Palestinians were killed Sunday by Israeli fire while trying to get food. It was the deadliest day for Palestinians seeking food under the new aid system.

item.title: Inside a Gaza hospital: A British surgeon on what he's witnessing firsthand
item.description: Dr. Nick Maynard tells NPR he's treating children shot at food distribution sites and witnessing what he believes is the systematic destruction of Gaza's civilian infrastructure.
